conversation.text: I would recommend "White Night" as a good choice for a piracy movie. The movie is about a pawnbroker who is found murdered in a remote town. Police suspect that he was murdered by an acquaintance, as even the most experienced investigator on the case could identify no signs of resistance. Three people come under suspicion but all of them have perfect alibis and the investigation comes to a standstill. One year later, one of them is found dead and the original murder case becomes even more mysterious. Almost fifteen years pass and the lead inspector, now approaching retirement, reflects on the only case he could not solve in an otherwise successful career. Haunted by a sense of responsibility and guilt that he caused suffering by letting the murder case go unsolved, he decides to re-investigate.

Based on your preference cues, I would recommend "The Rise of Theodore Roosevelt" (1979) as an excellent choice.

"The Rise of Theodore Roosevelt" is a historical drama film directed by William Friedkin, based on the Pulitzer Prize-winning book of the same name by Edmund Guller. The film follows the early life and rise to power of Theodore Roosevelt, a 26th President of the United States from 1903 to 1909.

The film is known for its sharp editing, powerful performances, and thought-provoking themes. Some notable highlights include:

- The memorable opening scene in which Theodore Roosevelt as a young man is shown.
- The tense and gripping encounter between Theodore Roosevelt and the British Lord不足爵士 (Lord不足爵士是英国政府中负责外交事务的官员的头衔)) at the London Carlton Hotel during the 1903 imperial visit of President Theodore Roosevelt to Great Britain.

Set in New York City during the 1940s, it follows a powerful Mafia dynasty called the Corleone Family, headed by the patriarch Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). As the family's business expands from criminal activities to legitimate business ventures, the family faces numerous challenges and conflicts within their own family members.
7. The Shawshank Redemption  (1994) - Directed by Frank Darabont, this drama film stars Tim Robbins, Matt Damon, and Michael Douglas. Set in the fictional state of Massachusetts during the 1930s through the 1950s, it follows two prisoners named Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) and Ellis Redding (Matt Damon), who have been separated from their families and sentenced to life imprisonment at Shawshank State Penitentiary in Maine.
As Andy and Ellis serve time behind bars at Shawshank State Penitentiary, they develop a bond of friendship through shared experiences of life on the inside of prison walls. As they share stories about their lives before prison, they realize that despite their differences, they are both human beings who have been hurt by others in the past.
As Andy and Ellis spend more time together in prison, they develop even closer bonds of friendship with each other through shared experiences of life on the inside of prison walls.
